title: James Gunn calls out Martin Scorsese for 'judging' Marvel movies
text:
James was ‘saddened’ by Martin’s comments (Picture: REX/ metro.co.uk)

James Gunn has called out Martin Scorsese for his claims that Marvel movies ‘aren’t cinema’, comparing the situation to the boycotts of The Last Temptation of Christ.

The Guardians Of The Galaxy director spoke out on social media about Martin’s comments.

‘Martin Scorsese is one of my 5 favorite living filmmakers. I was outraged when people picketed The Last Temptation of Christ without having seen the film. I’m saddened that he’s now judging my films in the same way,’ James wrote.

He went on to add: ‘That said, I will always love Scorsese, be grateful for his contribution to cinema, and can’t wait to see The Irishman.’

He spoke out on social media (Picture: Twitter/JamesGunn)

Scorcese’s movie The Last Temptation of Christ prompted boycotts from vocal Christian groups upon its release in 1988 due to its departures from gospel narratives.

James’ comments saw mixed reactions from fans – while some agreed with him and argued that Martin’s claims were unwarranted, others argued that the two situations can’t be compared.

The 53-year-old went on to write: ‘For those tweeting me I’m somehow saying zealots picketing Last Temptation is the same as Scorsese judging my films, I’m not. What outraged me about the picketers at the time of Last Temptation is NOT that they thought the film was blasphemous. Nor that they were picketing.

James later clarified his comments (Picture: Twitter/JamesGunn)

‘Doing those thing are within their rights. What bothered me was that 99% of them were doing it without having seen the movie.’

The Taxi Driver director faced backlash from Marvel die-hards when he spoke out about his ambivalence towards the franchise.

‘I tried, you know? But that’s not cinema,’ he told Empire magazine.

Avengers: Endgame is currently the highest-grossing movie of all time (Picture: Axelle/Bauer-Griffin/FilmMagic)

‘Honestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks. It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.’

Avengers: Endgame this year became the highest grossing film in history with a whopping $2,796,274,401 (£2,267,066,117) worldwide gross, while Avengers: Infinity War, The Avengers, Avengers: Age Of Ultron, Black Panther, Iron Man 3, Captain America: Civil War, Spider-Man: Far From Home and Captain Marvel are all in the top 30.

Marvel boss Kevin Feige previously defended the comic book blockbusters, saying last year at the Produced By conference: ‘Maybe it’s easy to dismiss VFX or flying people or spaceships or billion dollar grosses. I think it is easy to say that you have already been awarded in a certain way.

‘[Alfred] Hitchcock never won best director, so it’s very nice, but it doesn’t mean everything. I would much rather be in a room full of engaged fans.’
